claims.claim_text: A stack is a data structure that follows the principle of "Last In, First Out" (LIFO). It stores items with operations called push (adding an item) and pop (removing an item), similar to a pile of trays where the last tray placed on top is the first one taken off.
claims.top_evidence:
NOTES:
Stack A stack is a linear data structure which is used to store data items and follows the principle of Last In - First Out (LIFO). First In - Last Out (FILO): It is a considered list in which addition of new data items and deletion of existing data items is done from one end known as the top of the stack. The insertion and deletion operations in stack are known as push and pop operations.

claims.claim_text: A Last In - First Out (LIFO) data structure is a way to store information in a stack, where the last item added is the first one to be removed. This is similar to how trays work: when items are placed on a tray (pushed onto the stack), they go on top, and when items are taken off (popped from the stack), they come off the top first.
claims.top_evidence:
NOTES:
Stack A stack is a linear data structure which is used to store data items and follows the principle of Last In - First Out (LIFO). First In - Last Out (FILO): It is a considered list in which addition of new data items and deletion of existing data items is done from one end known as the top of the stack. The insertion and deletion operations in stack are known as push and pop operations.

claims.claim_text: First In - Last Out (FILO) is a principle that organizes data in a stack, a type of container used in computing. Data added first goes out last; the last item entered is the first one to leave. This principle is often applied through push and pop operations, where pushing adds an item to the top of the stack, and popping removes it from the top.
claims.top_evidence:

First In - Last Out (FILO): It is a considered list in which addition of new data items and deletion of existing data items is done from one end known as the top of the stack. The insertion and deletion operations in stack are known as push and pop operations.

claims.claim_text: The "Top of the Stack" refers to the last item added in a stack, which is the first one to be removed. This concept is essential as it helps determine the order of operations in a LIFO (Last In First Out) data structure.

claims.claim_text: A linear data structure is a type of organization for storing information sequentially, where each item is connected to the next one in a line. Examples include arrays, linked lists, and stacks (which follow the principle of Last In - First Out). Common operations on linear data structures are adding (push) or removing (pop) items from one end.
